Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Understanding Changing Seasonality, Variability and Extremes in the Northeast U.S. Climate
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will establish an integrated research, education and outreach program to understand changing climate in the Northeast (NE) United States.

The research will emphasize high resolution global multi-model ensembles being prepared for the Coupled Model Intercomparison Project (CMIP5). Analysis will include verification of models using both global and regional observations (temperature, precipitation, winds and moisture) and evaluation of projections for variables and timescales of importance to the region. Uncertainties will be examined using multi-model statistics. The objectives of this research are to evaluate and understand the drivers of 21st century probabilistic changes in: (a) the phase and amplitude of the mean annual cycle of climate variables, (b) the relationship between NE cold season precipitation and temperature variability associated with both tropical and mid-latitude sources, (c) the variability of warm season moisture transport into the Northeast and the relationship of soil moisture to temperature and precipitation variability, and (d) indices of extremes, the frequency and intensity of cold season cyclones, the intensity and duration of extreme heat, and their modulation by decadal variations.

The education and outreach will focus on (a) training a postdoctoral researcher, a graduate student and undergraduates in the climate science specialty of geography, (b) developing a new upper division honors course on climate change science which includes an outreach/service learning component, (c) adding new project-related content to a large-enrollment, introductory course on climate, (d) developing geographic information system (GIS) based web portal for visualizing probabilistic climate change projections for Connecticut/NE, (e) sharing research results and findings with the Connecticut Governor?s Steering Committee (GSC) and Adaptation Subcommittee on Climate Change, and with other NE state and regional impacts and adaptation policy efforts.

Broader impacts of this project are primarily educational and in the potential to advance understanding of current and especially future climate means, variability and extremes and of mechanisms leading to greater confidence in projections in the northeastern US, which has important societal benefits.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

Northeast Annual Cycle:  Our examination of the U.S. Northeast annual cycles suggests that there is information contained in month-to-month projected changes in temperature and precipitation that has not been exploited. Climate model projections of temperature increases are largest in mid-winter (Dec-Feb) and late summer (Jul-Sep). Precipitation increases peak in late winter/early spring (Feb-Apr) and climate models show strong disagreement regarding the direction of changein late summer. Yet there is model agreement in the timing of changes, indicating that there is important information in the annual cycle that warrants further attention. (Lynch, Seth, and Thibeault, JClimate, 2016)

Northeast Variability:We examined summertime year-to-year variability in the U.S. Northeast, and first created a framework to evaluate regional climate processes in climate models. Our observational analyses showed that wet summers in the northeast region are associated with low pressure centered near the Great Lakes (western Atlantic east of the Mid-Atlantic states), northeastward moisture flow and increased moisture convergence along the Eastern Seaboard (off the U.S. Southeast coast), and anomalous high pressure in the western Atlantic related to southwest ridging of the North Atlantic anticyclone (Thibeault and Seth, JClimate 2014).

We next examined these regional processes in global and regional climate model simulations of recent climate in order to establish model credibility in future projections. While climate models adequately simulate most large-scale circulation features present during wet Northeast summers, all have errors in simulating increased sea level pressure and moisture divergence in the western tropical Atlantic. No single model was identified as clearly more credible, but six models performed consistently better than the rest. Among these bettermodels, there is no consistency in the direction of future summer precipitation change. Thus, our analysis suggests that the Northeast precipitation response to greenhouse warming is dependent on changes in the North Atlantic subtropical high and associated circulation and moisture transport patterns, which vary among even among the better models.  (Thibeault and Seth, JGR, 2015).  A collaboration with colleagues at the University of Massachusetts has focused on identifying both credible and diverse climate models for regional climate analyses (Karmalkar et al., Climatic Change, 2018).

Extremes:Our study of changing climate extremes provides a regional analysis and verification of the latest generation of global climate models specifically for the Northeast, useful to stakeholders focused on understanding and adapting to climate change and its impacts in the region. Climate extremes indices were evaluated for the Northeast United States using observations and twenty-three global climate models. We found a significant shift towards more precipitation in the distribution of observed annual total annual between 1981-2010. In addition, significant increasing trends are seen in all observed wet extreme indices over 1951-2010. For the Northeast region, models project significant shifts in the distributions of most temperature and precipitation indices by mid-century (2041-2070). By the late century, the future cold extremes are projected to be warmer than the warmest extremes at present. (Thibeault and Seth, Climatic Change, 2014). Future work is planned on heat extremes and health outcomes in the Northeast.

 

Broader Impacts

1. The research from this program has resulted in a request (by CT DEEP and the Ct Institute for Resilience and Climate Adaptation - CIRCA) for the PI to lead a physical climate assessment for the state of CT. The draft assessment is currently under revision. (CT Physical Climate Science Assessment - CTPCSAR, 2018)

2. To begin the assessment a workshop was held in Nov 2017 on methods/practices for state-level climate assessment. A manuscript is in preparation discussing the unique aspects of state/local assessments and the need to establish best practices (Kirchhoff, et al., BAMS, 2018)

3. Students and postdocs trained by this program are now in roles where they can educate others.  One PhD graduate is now an analyst in the climate change office at CT Department of Energy and Environmental Protection (DEEP). Our post-doctoral researcher has continued to conduct research in the PI's Climate Lab and teaches climate-related courses at the UConn. An undergraduate intern was also a student leader in UConn@COP23 and is now working for the CT Council for Climate and Jobs.  

4. This program has created a full suite of three undergraduate courses on climate science that provide a foundation for UConn's Physical Geography, Environmental Studies, Environmental Sciences, Environmental Engineering, and a number of other undergraduate majors. During the period of this award, more than 1200 students have been exposed to the basic science of climate over 14 weeks.

5. The UConn@COP program was an unexpected, but critical outcome made possible by this program, wherein 28 top-achieving undergraduates with a passion for environment from across campus (science, human rights, medicine, ecology) have participated in the annual UN Climate summits since Paris in 2015. This program has significant momentum and will continue, as the need for leadership is critical.
